Award.AwardTitle: Primate dental topographic and geometric morphology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the morphology of the teeth is vital for paleontologists analyzing mammalian evolution, both for the identification of species and for assessing relationships between different species and groups. Additionally, as teeth function primarily to process food, the dentition provides information on diet in fossil primates. The goals of the project are to gain a better understanding of the relative contribution of dietary specialization, phylogenetic history and body size to primate dental morphology, and to test hypotheses concerning best practice in the use of dental morphology to reconstruct diet and phylogenetic history. This will be accomplished through the compilation, measurement, and analysis of a large sample of three dimensional (3D) digital images of dental morphology from all major groupings of extant primates, and fossil species from key periods in primate evolution.

This research contributes to building scientific infrastructure through the creation of a database of digital images, which will be made available to other researchers and students for teaching and research purposes. When requested by museums providing access to specimens, high quality dental casts and digital images will also be archived with these institutions. The project also will provide training for undergraduate students in the creation of anatomical images from computed tomography, a technique that is employed extensively in medical practice, and similar digital images also are used in the fields of architecture, art, and engineering. This work will be carried out at Brooklyn College, and will promote undergraduate participation in scientific research through providing opportunities for employment as research assistants, and through associated exercises that will form part of the coursework in classes taught by the principal investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We know not to look a gift horse in the mouth, but the surprising thing about the “horse’s mouth” is that its teeth convey all the information one needs to distinguish a horse from any other mammal, including its close relatives such as donkeys and zebras.  And it’s not just horses, look at a couple of teeth of most mammals and without any other information experts can diagnose the species. For animals that are extinct and for which DNA is not available, the teeth are invaluable to scientists who want to determine where those extinct species fit in the tree of life. If this seems odd because you thought teeth were there to chop and chew food, you’d be correct.  In fact, researchers also use teeth to reconstruct an extinct mammal’s diet and the ecological profile of extinct communities.

One problem working with teeth is that they are very difficult to measure because they are such complex and often tiny objects. As a result, much of the work done with them has been qualitative. This has created a communication gap between generations of scientists and also prevents rigorous testing of ideas about whether dental features reflect diet or evolutionary relationships (phylogeny).  Another wrinkle is that often--when relationships are not clear after looking at one tooth--researchers will look at other teeth of the animal to see if they push the diagnosis in one direction or another. The problem here is that adjacent teeth may not provide independent evidence, since they were created by the same genetic program. If teeth are non-independent, it would be better to look at additional parts of the skeleton to resolve phylogeny questions than to count features in multiple teeth of the same dentition.

In this project, we advanced understanding of tooth form for the mammalian order Primates (including lemurs, tarsiers, monkeys, apes and humans) by taking a digital approach. We made 3D models of over 3,000 teeth using a high resolution ct scan of either the real specimen or a high fidelity resin cast. Working from 3D models allowed us to take highly precise and detailed measurements necessary for figuring out how much teeth reveal about phylogeny versus dietary ecology, and to do this in a way that other researchers could easily replicate.  The digital modality of our data also makes it very easy to share with other researchers. We have already published a large amount of data from this project on a publically accessible archive called www.morphosource.org. Anyone can search for and view in 3D in their web browser the tooth models we made and measured for this project.

This project has so far resulted in 11 peer reviewed papers and 7 conference presentations. We have provided the first thorough analyses showing that (1) topography of teeth, when properly quantified predominantly reflect diet, though phylogeny has an impact; (2) non-molar teeth have a strong dietary signal when measured topographically; (3) the topographic information in one tooth position can be redundant with(non-independent from) that in other teeth from the same jaw, which should lead systematists to use caution; (4) when teeth are quantified according to their detailed anatomy (geometric morphometrics), rather than topography alone, there is still a strong dietary signal, and (5) the tooth geometry is independent of the size of the tooth. Despite the dietary connection, we found that we could also identify teeth to the proper species using the geometric information with greater than 90% accuracy. This was true whether a scientist collected the geometric information from the scans or an algorithm (newly developed and one of the outcomes of this work) automatically extracted that information.
